comment.author: 69662531@N05
comment._content:
From the Commonwealth War Graves Commission website:

Name:OLDERSHAW, JOHN JOSEPH FRITZ
Initials:J J F
Nationality:United Kingdom
Rank:Second Lieutenant
Regiment/Service:King's Own Yorkshire Light Infantry
Unit Text:9th Bn.
Age:23
Date of Death:01/07/1916
Additional information:Son of John and Mary Elizabeth Oldershaw, of Bunny, Nottingham. B.Sc. (London University).
Casualty Type:Commonwealth War Dead
Grave/Memorial Reference:Pier and Face 11 C and 12 A.
Memorial:THIEPVAL MEMORIAL

comment.author: 69645150@N05
comment._content: John Joseph Fritz Oldershaw was born in 1893 at Costock in Leicestershire.  In 1911 he was a  student at Nottingham University College.

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/coolshanagh55]  Hi Coolshanagh25, thank you for this (and your otehr contributions elsewhere). if you had a moment, could you let us know where you found this information. Thank you again.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: An intruiging entry in the London Gazette of 23rd March 1915 [p.18 of Issue 29109] cancels the Temporary Commission as 2Lt of 12 infantry officers, including John Joseph Fritz Oldershaw, whose Commission was originally published in the London Gazette of 18th December 1914.//

comment.author: 10807052@N04
comment._content: Gary, that was due to Oldershaw being commissioned TWICE- both times on the Infantry's General List.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: Frank, thank you, and well done, for resolving that little puzzle, the answer had completely eluded me. At battlefields1418.50megs.com/9koyli.htm there is a photograph, found by Mr Paul Reed, of the officers of 9 KOYLI taken at La Neuville, Corbie, in April 1916. Fritz Oldershaw ought to be amongst them - my best guess is that he is the man last right on the rear row. Mr Reed quotes there from the memoirs of Captain Lancelot Spicer, from the evening of 30th June 1916; "Of those present, twenty-four went into action next day in the attack on Fricourt. Six were in reserve. Of the twenty-four, twelve were killed, including Lynch and Haswell. Three died of wounds afterwards, eight were wounded, one slightly and only one left untouched."//

comment.author: 10807052@N04
comment._content: The gut on the back row far right does look very much like Lieutenant Oldershaw.  I do have a captioned version of this picture, although some of the captions are wrong.

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content: John Joseph Fritz Oldershaw was probably born at Glebe Farm, Costock, Nottinghamshire www.geograph.org.uk/photo/7975 It is here that the family farmed in 1901. John was 7, his siblings were much older: Christine (19), Albert W (18) and George H (15). His parents were John (53) and Mary Elizabeth (46). Costock Village Website has some old photographs of the village costockvillage.com/local_area.htm By 1911 only John was still at home, aged 17 and a Student at Notts University College. The Oldershaws had two grandchildren in the household on census night: Christine's children Elsie Kathleen and Sidney Walter Smerton aged 4 and 3 respectively. Probate was granted 6 March 1917 to Albert William Oldershaw, agricultural organiser. Effects £261 18s 10d.
